elements.content: In the quest for new synthetic strategies for designing new magnetic metal–organic frameworks, two manganese(II) butyrate-based compounds have been synthesized and characterized for the first time. Both compounds have been studied in depth by single crystal X-ray diffraction and powder neutron diffraction, thermogravimetric analysis, differential scanning calorimetry, SQUID magnetometry, and FTIR spectroscopy. The structures of both compounds are different from the typical lamellar one of most of metal alkanoates. The first one (hexamanganese(II) hydroxy undecabutanoate) presents an isostructural solid-to-solid transition at low temperature, with a packing of corrugated layers (2D coordination polymer) in a monoclinic unit cell (P21/n), while the other one (diaqua pentamanganese(II) decabutanoate) shows a 3D framework in a cubic lattice (Ia-3). The magnetic properties of both systems reveal the existence of an overall antiferromagnetic interaction involving an extensive exchange coupling network. These polynuclear complexes show that short metal alkanoates of transition metals, or even, mixed ligand complexes could be a way to design compounds with interesting properties (magnetic, porous, ...).

elements.content:
“Manganese(II) butyrate-based MOFs: Structures, and Thermal and Magnetic Properties”.

Introduction

The great attention drawn in the last years by metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), reflected in the huge number of papers devoted to this emerging class of crystalline inorganic–organic hybrid materials, is due to the diversity of potential applications, ranging from sensing, catalysis, and separation to multifunctionality. The possibility of obtaining a multifunctional material comes from the modular structure and flexibility for structural design of these compounds. Thanks to the use of constitutive transition-metal ions within the framework of the structure, magnetic MOFs are probably the most abundant multifunctional materials of this type. In the search for new synthetic strategies for the obtaining of new magnetic MOFs with interesting properties, we have set our attention into the poorly studied family of metal alkanoates.
elements.clean_text:
"Manganese(II) butyrate-based MOFs: Structures, and Thermal and Magnetic Properties".

Introduction

The great attention drawn in the last years by metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), reflected in the huge number of papers devoted to this emerging class of crystalline inorganic-organic hybrid materials, is due to the diversity of potential applications, ranging from sensing, catalysis, and separation to multifunctionality. The possibility of obtaining a multifunctional material comes from the modular structure and flexibility for structural design of these compounds. Thanks to the use of constitutive transition-metal ions within the framework of the structure, magnetic MOFs are probably the most abundant multifunctional materials of this type. In the search for new synthetic strategies for the obtaining of new magnetic MOFs with interesting properties, we have set our attention into the poorly studied family of metal alkanoates.

elements.content: Metal alkanoates, commonly known as metal soaps, belong to the more general family of organic salts, which owe their importance to their characteristic amphiphilic structure: organic and inorganic. Specifically, metal alkanoates present interesting properties not only as surfactants in solution, but also as pure compounds for the polymorphism and polymesomorphism (liquid crystal, rotator or condis phases) they may present.
elements.clean_text: Metal alkanoates, commonly known as metal soaps, belong to the more general family of organic salts, which owe their importance to their characteristic amphiphilic structure: organic and inorganic. Specifically, metal alkanoates present interesting properties not only as surfactants in solution, but also as pure compounds for the polymorphism and polymesomorphism (liquid crystal, rotator or condis phases) they may present.

elements.content: Many metal alkanoate series have been studied so far, specially alkali, alkali-earth and others like thallium(I), lead(II), copper(II), zinc, or, recently, some lanthanide metals. However, there is a lack of information (thermal, crystallographic, magnetic, etc.) about many transition metals alkanoates (apart from Cu and Zn). Only a few generic studies were carried out in some long manganese(II) alkanoates.

However, there is a lack of information (thermal, crystallographic, magnetic, etc.) about many transition metals alkanoates (apart from Cu and Zn). Only a few generic studies were carried out in some long manganese(II) alkanoates.

elements.content: Normally, these compounds are not very interesting from the structural point of view due to their typical “membrane-like” (bilayered) structure: they are usually 2-Dimensional (2D) coordination polymers in the crystal phase, with alternating ionic and lipidic layers. This is also frequent for mixed metal alkanoates. In other cases, as for copper(II) alkanoates, a 1D structure is obtained. Thus, it is rather rare for this kind of salt to present a 3D structure due to the steric hindrance in the alkyl chains packing (hydrophobic nuclei), and so has been uniquely detected some hydrated short alkanoates, and a four calcium-based mixed alkanoates, and, recently, for the anhydrous lithium acetate polymorphs and its hydrates, and lithium and lead(II) tributyrate.

This is also frequent for mixed metal alkanoates. In other cases, as for copper(II) alkanoates, a 1D structure is obtained. Thus, it is rather rare for this kind of salt to present a 3D structure due to the steric hindrance in the alkyl chains packing (hydrophobic nuclei), and so has been uniquely detected some hydrated short alkanoates, and a four calcium-based mixed alkanoates, and, recently, for the anhydrous lithium acetate polymorphs and its hydrates, and lithium and lead(II) tributyrate.

elements.content: The selection of the butyrate ligand (the butyrate anion is referred as but, from now on) among the different alkanoate ligands was taken as a compromise between the steric interaction of the hydrophobic tails and the ability of the short tail alkanoate ligands (formate and acetatate) to form extended networks. The ability of this carboxylate ligand to transmit the magnetic exchange coupling in butyrate compounds has been studied in the dinuclear units present in [{Cu(but)2(H2O)}2] compound, showing an antiferromagnetic coupling through the syn-syn carboxylate ligand, and in the oxo-centered trinuclear Mn complex [Mn3O(but)6(C5H5N)3]·ClO4 reported by Jun et al., also with a global antiferromagnetic behavior where the butyrate ligands act also as syn-syn connectors. The well-known chemistry of metal carboxylates, where the carboxylate groups can coordinate in a huge number of different ways to the central metal ion, remains by now unexplored for butyrate compounds, where the coordination modes of the carboxylate groups in combination with transition metal ions show a predominance to the syn-syn coordination mode, according to the literature.

The ability of this carboxylate ligand to transmit the magnetic exchange coupling in butyrate compounds has been studied in the dinuclear units present in [{Cu(but)2(H2O)}2] compound, showing an antiferromagnetic coupling through the syn-syn carboxylate ligand, and in the oxo-centered trinuclear Mn complex [Mn3O(but)6(C5H5N)3]⋅ClO4 reported by Jun et al., also with a global antiferromagnetic behavior where the butyrate ligands act also as syn-syn connectors. The well-known chemistry of metal carboxylates, where the carboxylate groups can coordinate in a huge number of different ways to the central metal ion, remains by now unexplored for butyrate compounds, where the coordination modes of the carboxylate groups in combination with transition metal ions show a predominance to the syn-syn coordination mode, according to the literature.

elements.content: In this work, two new manganese butyrate-based compounds, one with a hydroxyl group (1) and the other with two coordinating water molecules (2) have been studied. The synthetic routes described in this work allow obtaining new coordination modes of the carboxylate groups (see Scheme ), that give rise to the unprecedented crystal structures of 1 and 2. The formulas of this two compounds are [Mn6(but)11(OH)] n (1) and [Mn5(but)10(H2O)2] n (2); the first one shows a corrugated layer structure (2D MOF) while the second shows an unprecedented 3D structure. The crystal structure determination was carried out involving synchrotron X-ray diffraction. The magnetic behavior, studied by means of SQUID magnetometry in the 2–300 K temperature range, reveals antiferromagnetic interactions in both compounds. The possibility of ferrimagnetic behavior in compound 2 was studied with SQUID and neutron diffraction measurements. The isostructural solid–solid phase transition observed in the thermal studies of compound 1 was corroborated through powder neutron diffraction.
elements.clean_text: In this work, two new manganese butyrate-based compounds, one with a hydroxyl group (1) and the other with two coordinating water molecules (2) have been studied. The synthetic routes described in this work allow obtaining new coordination modes of the carboxylate groups (see Scheme ), that give rise to the unprecedented crystal structures of 1 and 2. The formulas of this two compounds are [Mn6(but)11(OH)] n  (1) and [Mn5(but)10(H2O)2] n  (2); the first one shows a corrugated layer structure (2D MOF) while the second shows an unprecedented 3D structure. The crystal structure determination was carried out involving synchrotron X-ray diffraction. The magnetic behavior, studied by means of SQUID magnetometry in the 2-300 K temperature range, reveals antiferromagnetic interactions in both compounds. The possibility of ferrimagnetic behavior in compound 2 was studied with SQUID and neutron diffraction measurements. The isostructural solid-solid phase transition observed in the thermal studies of compound 1 was corroborated through powder neutron diffraction.

elements.content: To synthesize compound 1, an aqueous solution (150 mL) of 50 mmol of MnCl2.4H2O (Sigma Aldrich, ≥99%), and 100 mmol of butyric acid (Fluka, ≥99.5%), was prepared first. The pH was adjusted to a value of 5.0 by dropwise addition of an aqueous solution of Sodium hydroxide 1 M (NaOH, Sigma Ultra, ≥98%). The solvent was partially extracted from the solution in a rotavapor, until a light pink color solution was reached. Single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction as light pink flake prisms were obtained by slow evaporation at room temperature within a week. The sample was cleaned with a small volume of deionized water.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Sample Preparation

Synthesis of [Mn6(but)11(OH)] n  (1)

To synthesize compound 1, an aqueous solution (150 mL) of 50 mmol of MnCl2.4H2O (Sigma Aldrich, ≥99%), and 100 mmol of butyric acid (Fluka, ≥99.5%), was prepared first. The pH was adjusted to a value of 5.0 by dropwise addition of an aqueous solution of Sodium hydroxide 1 M (NaOH, Sigma Ultra, ≥98%). The solvent was partially extracted from the solution in a rotavapor, until a light pink color solution was reached. Single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction as light pink flake prisms were obtained by slow evaporation at room temperature within a week. The sample was cleaned with a small volume of deionized water.

elements.content: Compound 2 can be prepared following two methods. The first method consists in mixing the aforementioned aqueous solution with 2-propanol (Sigma, ≥ 99%), in a 1:1 ratio between both solvents. Large cubic crystals were obtained by slow evaporation. This compound can be obtained by a second method, by a chemical reaction between MnCO3 (Sigma Aldrich, 99.99%) and butyric acid, in excess, heating under reflux for five hours, in deionized water. Crystals are also obtained by slow evaporation from this solution. The sample was cleaned with acetone (Sigma Aldrich, ≥99.5%), to extract the excess of butyric acid.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Mn5(but)10(H2O)2] n  (2)

Compound 2 can be prepared following two methods. The first method consists in mixing the aforementioned aqueous solution with 2-propanol (Sigma, ≥ 99%), in a 1:1 ratio between both solvents. Large cubic crystals were obtained by slow evaporation. This compound can be obtained by a second method, by a chemical reaction between MnCO3 (Sigma Aldrich, 99.99%) and butyric acid, in excess, heating under reflux for five hours, in deionized water. Crystals are also obtained by slow evaporation from this solution. The sample was cleaned with acetone (Sigma Aldrich, ≥99.5%), to extract the excess of butyric acid.

elements.content: Some crystals were chosen for compound 1 and 2, flake shaped and cubic, respectively, to study their structures by Single Crystal X-ray Diffraction. The sizes of the crystals used are given in Table .

elements.content: Some crystals were chosen for compounds 1 and 2, flake shaped and cubic, respectively, to study their structures by SCXRD. X-ray measurements were conducted using synchrotron radiation (with λ = 0.7514 Å) at the BM16 Spanish beamline of ESRF with a CCD detector (ADSCq210rCCD), making phi scans when collecting the data. The oscillation range (Δφ) used for each image was one degree, in all of the cases. Each compound was measured at two different temperatures: 100 and 298 K. After several measurements crystals of compound 1 suffer some radiation damage.
elements.clean_text:
Single Crystal X-ray Diffraction (SCXRD)

Some crystals were chosen for compounds 1 and 2, flake shaped and cubic, respectively, to study their structures by SCXRD. X-ray measurements were conducted using synchrotron radiation (with λ = 0.7514 Å) at the BM16 Spanish beamline of ESRF with a CCD detector (ADSCq210rCCD), making phi scans when collecting the data. The oscillation range (Δφ) used for each image was one degree, in all of the cases. Each compound was measured at two different temperatures: 100 and 298 K. After several measurements crystals of compound 1 suffer some radiation damage.

elements.content: The structures were solved by direct methods and subsequent Fourier syntheses using the SHELXS-97 program and were refined by the full-matrix least-squares technique against F2 using with the SHELXL-97 program. Anisotropic thermal parameters were used to refine all non-H atoms. The treatment of the hydrogen atoms was mixed for both samples: the position of the hydrogens of the hydroxyl group and of the coordinating water molecules, for compounds 1 and 2, respectively, were refined, while the alkyl chain hydrogens were calculated geometrically. In the case of compound 2, some carbon atoms are found to be disordered across two sites for four butyrates, at 100 K, and for only two of them, at 298 K. However, for both salts, the thermal ellipsoids for all of the atoms are much bigger at room temperature than at 100 K, as expected.

The treatment of the hydrogen atoms was mixed for both samples: the position of the hydrogens of the hydroxyl group and of the coordinating water molecules, for compounds 1 and 2, respectively, were refined, while the alkyl chain hydrogens were calculated geometrically. In the case of compound 2, some carbon atoms are found to be disordered across two sites for four butyrates, at 100 K, and for only two of them, at 298 K. However, for both salts, the thermal ellipsoids for all of the atoms are much bigger at room temperature than at 100 K, as expected.

Both [Mn6(but)11(OH)] n and [Mn5(but)10(H2O)2] n samples were measured on the high intensity neutron powder diffractometer D1B at the Institut Laue Langevin (Grenoble, France). The sample was contained in a 6 mm cylindrical vanadium-can inside a vanadium-tailed Orange Cryostat. The diffraction patterns were recorded using a wavelength λ = 2.523 Å over a scattering vector range 0.07 < Q < 3.2 Å–1, performing temperature scans from 1.5 K to room temperature. The structures were refined by the Rietveld method using the Fullprof package programs.
elements.clean_text:
Neutron Powder Diffraction

Both [Mn6(but)11(OH)] n  and [Mn5(but)10(H2O)2] n  samples were measured on the high intensity neutron powder diffractometer D1B at the Institut Laue Langevin (Grenoble, France). The sample was contained in a 6 mm cylindrical vanadium-can inside a vanadium-tailed Orange Cryostat. The diffraction patterns were recorded using a wavelength λ = 2.523 Å over a scattering vector range 0.07 < Q < 3.2 Å-1, performing temperature scans from 1.5 K to room temperature. The structures were refined by the Rietveld method using the Fullprof package programs.

elements.content: A TA Instruments DSC, Model Q10, connected to a RCS cooling unit, was used to register all the thermograms, for temperatures from 200 to 600 K. Low temperature measurements were carried out using a Q100 calorimeter, using a Liquid Nitrogen Cooling System allowing to reach ∼98 K. Tightly sealed aluminum volatile pans were used, in dry nitrogen, flowing at 50.0 mL·min–1. A MT5Mettler microbalance was used to weigh the samples, ranging between 3 and 10 mg (with an error of ±0.001 mg). The calorimeter was calibrated in temperature using standard samples of In and Sn, supplied by TA (purity >99.999% and >99.9%, respectively), and of benzoic acid (purity>99.97%), supplied by the former NBS (lot 39i), and in enthalpy with the In and Sn standards already described.

Spectra of powder samples were recorded with a Golden Gate ATR device on a Bruker IFS 28 FTIR spectrometer with a resolution of 4 cm–1 at ambient temperature.

SQUID Magnetometry

Magnetic susceptibility measurements on polycrystalline samples (crushed single crystals) of compounds 1 and 2 were carried out in the temperature range 1.9–300 K with a Quantum Design SQUID magnetometer under an applied magnetic field ranged from 100 and 10000 G. Corrections for the diamagnetic contribution of the constituent atoms were done from Pascal’s constants as well as the corrections for the magnetization of the sample holder were done.

elements.content:
The structures of the two manganese(II) butyrate-based salts were solved and refined by SCXRD. The main characteristics of these frameworks are described below:

Compound <bold>1</bold> ([Mn<sub>6</sub>(but)<sub>11</sub>(OH)]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub>)

This compound shows a monoclinic unit cell (P21/n), with a structure growing in corrugated layers (2D), across the (1,0,-1) plane, partially parallel to the planes (1,-1,-1) and (1,1,-1) (see Figure A). The layers show a regular packing (with an ABAB stacking sequence), being 23.527(4) and 25.279(4) Å the distance between adjacent A planes at 100 and 298 K, respectively. Regarding the ionic layers, the manganese ions are connected among them involving μ-COO, μ-OH, and different carboxylate bridges describing two different kinds of rings, formed by 18 and 10 manganese atoms, respectively (Figure B). These rings are parallel to the planes (1,-1,-1) and (1,1,-1), forming the corrugated layer structure. The alkyl chains of the butyrate ligands grow upward and downward the ionic planes (manganese atoms and carboxylates). The weak Van der Walls interaction among the alkyls tails of the different planes keeps the layers together, reaching the final 3D assemble observed in Figure A.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

X-ray Diffraction

The structures of the two manganese(II) butyrate-based salts were solved and refined by SCXRD. The main characteristics of these frameworks are described below:

Compound 1 ([Mn6(but)11(OH)] n )

This compound shows a monoclinic unit cell (P21/n), with a structure growing in corrugated layers (2D), across the (1,0,-1) plane, partially parallel to the planes (1,-1,-1) and (1,1,-1) (see Figure A). The layers show a regular packing (with an ABAB stacking sequence), being 23.527(4) and 25.279(4) Å the distance between adjacent A planes at 100 and 298 K, respectively. Regarding the ionic layers, the manganese ions are connected among them involving μ-COO, μ-OH, and different carboxylate bridges describing two different kinds of rings, formed by 18 and 10 manganese atoms, respectively (Figure B). These rings are parallel to the planes (1,-1,-1) and (1,1,-1), forming the corrugated layer structure. The alkyl chains of the butyrate ligands grow upward and downward the ionic planes (manganese atoms and carboxylates). The weak Van der Walls interaction among the alkyls tails of the different planes keeps the layers together, reaching the final 3D assemble observed in Figure A.

elements.content: There are six crystallographically independent Mn(II) atoms [from Mn(1) to Mn(6)] in the asymmetric unit. Mn(1), Mn(2), Mn(3), and Mn(4) are six coordinated in slightly distorted octahedral environment. While Mn(5) and Mn(6) are as well as six coordinated but present a trigonal prismatic coordination, chelated by μ4-carboxylates. Mn(1), Mn(2), and Mn(4) have the same surrounding, each manganese atom have a coordination sphere of five carboxylate-oxygen atoms and one hydroxo oxygen atom (O1H). The hydroxo group, which is shared between the three manganese ions, shows a slightly distorted tetrahedral environment. Mn(3) is surrounding by six oxygen atom form six different carboxylate groups, while Mn(5) and Mn(6) are six coordinated involving the oxygen atoms from five different carboxylate groups (Figure C).

The hydroxyl anion coordinates three manganese atoms.

elements.content: From the SCXRD measurements at 100 and 298 K, no significant differences are found regarding the distances between the atoms in both structures. Only slight changes, related with the bending of the alkyl chains (see Figure D), are found in the unit cell. However, the thermal ellipsoids for all of the atoms at 298 K are much bigger, indicating the ease to present dynamical disorder, especially in the alkyl chains.

elements.content: This compound presents a cubic cell (Ia-3), forming a microporous -3D framework (Figure A), where four kind of channels coexists, two of them are hydrophobic, which have the alkyl tails from the butyrate ligands inside it, and the other two, hydrophilic where the different crystallization water molecules (O1w and O2w) and the non coordinated oxygen atoms from the butyrate ligands are located [see Figure a–c]. The inorganic network is built up from five crystallographically independent Mn(II) atoms, which are linked among them form a extensive network of different bridges, involving two coordinating water molecules, and ten butyrate ligands, which have been defined by the carbon atom from their carboxylate groups, as but(1) [C(1)], but(2) [C(5)], but(3) [C(9)], but(4) [C(13)], but(5) [C(17)], but(6) [C(21)], but(7) [C(25)], but(8) [C(29)], but(9) [C(33)], and but(10) [C(37)].

Compound 2 ([Mn5(but)10(H2O)2] n )

The inorganic network is built up from five crystallographically independent Mn(II) atoms, which are linked among them form a extensive network of different bridges, involving two coordinating water molecules, and ten butyrate ligands, which have been defined by the carbon atom from their carboxylate groups, as but(1) [C(1)], but(2) [C(5)], but(3) [C(9)], but(4) [C(13)], but(5) [C(17)], but(6) [C(21)], but(7) [C(25)], but(8) [C(29)], but(9) [C(33)], and but(10) [C(37)].

elements.content: All of the Mn atom (Mn(1) to Mn(5)) in the asymmetric show the same environment, coordinated by six O atoms and forming practically regular octahedral in every case. The water molecules present in this compound form a μ-oxo bridge between two Mn atoms (Figure B). Regarding the inorganic structure, the hydrophobic channels are built up from Mn(1) and Mn(5) ions and those symmetry related, form a ring of twelve manganese(II) ions, linked by the following ligands: but(4), but(5), but(8), and but(9) and O2w (see Figure C). A similar ring is formed by Mn(2) and Mn(3) and symmetry related ions which are linked through but(1), but(6), but(7), and but(10) and O1w. These hydrophilic cycles are joined among them, involving the Mn(4) ions and but(2) and but(3) ligands, giving rise, also, to the hydrophobic cavities (see Figure C).

elements.content: As explained in Section , although two different sites were found for some C atoms in four alkyl chains at 100 K, and only two at 298 K, a bigger disorder was found in the thermal ellipsoids at room temperature. It is important to note that the alkyl chains partially occupy the pores, with room enough to present some kind of disorder, as it happens in the case of the complex LiPb(C4)3, with a very similar structure with micropores. Thus, the thermal ellipsoid sizes of the β, γ, and δ-C atoms are much bigger than for the other atoms.

elements.content: A rapid survey for possible phase transitions in the temperature range from 1.5 to 300 K was undertaken by means of powder neutron diffraction as a function of temperature (Figure ). The powder neutron diffraction experiment allows confirming that, as observed by macroscopic magnetic measurements (see Section ), no long-range magnetic ordering occurs down to 1.5 K in any of the two compounds. However, from the structural point of view, while in compound 2 no significant change is noticed in the diffraction patterns apart from the increase of the lattice parameters, a discontinuity in the evolution of the these parameters is observed between 130 and 200 K for compound 1. Figure shows the evolution of the lattice parameters, which has been calculated from Rietveld refinements at selected temperatures, taking the SCXRD structures as starting point. Taking into account that small differences are found between the structures resolved at 100 and 298 K by SCXRD, this discontinuity probably corresponds to an isostructural solid–solid transition as observed in the related lithium pentanoate compound. The decrease of 6.6% (403 Å3) in the cell volume from 298 to 100 K, is related to the bending of the alkyl chains.
elements.clean_text:
Neutron Diffraction

A rapid survey for possible phase transitions in the temperature range from 1.5 to 300 K was undertaken by means of powder neutron diffraction as a function of temperature (Figure ). The powder neutron diffraction experiment allows confirming that, as observed by macroscopic magnetic measurements (see Section ), no long-range magnetic ordering occurs down to 1.5 K in any of the two compounds. However, from the structural point of view, while in compound 2 no significant change is noticed in the diffraction patterns apart from the increase of the lattice parameters, a discontinuity in the evolution of the these parameters is observed between 130 and 200 K for compound 1. Figure  shows the evolution of the lattice parameters, which has been calculated from Rietveld refinements at selected temperatures, taking the SCXRD structures as starting point. Taking into account that small differences are found between the structures resolved at 100 and 298 K by SCXRD, this discontinuity probably corresponds to an isostructural solid-solid transition as observed in the related lithium pentanoate compound. The decrease of 6.6% (403 Å3) in the cell volume from 298 to 100 K, is related to the bending of the alkyl chains.

elements.content:
The thermal study, both Thermogravimetric Analysis (TGA) and Differential Scanning Calorimetry (DSC), was carried out for the two compounds.

The thermal behavior of compound 2 seems to be simpler than 1 and helps to explain the latter’s decomposition (Figure ). In this sense, salt 2 presents three features: the water loss, the fusion of the anhydrous alkanoate, and the final decomposition producing MnO (Figure B). According to the type of water in compound 2, coordination water, its loss takes place at temperatures above 373 K. Thus, two endothermic peaks are observed by DSC, at 388.5 and 398.0 K. After this process, a fusion of the dehydrated salt, [Mn(but)2] n , is observed at 482.3 K. The anhydrous salt (manganese(II) butyrate) remains stable in the second and following heatings, up to a temperature of around 500 K, where it starts to decompose. This decomposition finishes at around 650 K, producing a residue of MnO, as assessed by TGA.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Analysis (TGA and DSC)

The thermal study, both Thermogravimetric Analysis (TGA) and Differential Scanning Calorimetry (DSC), was carried out for the two compounds.

The thermal behavior of compound 2 seems to be simpler than 1 and helps to explain the latter's decomposition (Figure ). In this sense, salt 2 presents three features: the water loss, the fusion of the anhydrous alkanoate, and the final decomposition producing MnO (Figure B). According to the type of water in compound 2, coordination water, its loss takes place at temperatures above 373 K. Thus, two endothermic peaks are observed by DSC, at 388.5 and 398.0 K. After this process, a fusion of the dehydrated salt, [Mn(but)2] n , is observed at 482.3 K. The anhydrous salt (manganese(II) butyrate) remains stable in the second and following heatings, up to a temperature of around 500 K, where it starts to decompose. This decomposition finishes at around 650 K, producing a residue of MnO, as assessed by TGA.

elements.content: In the case of compound 1, a solid-to-solid transition (SII–SI) was detected by DSC at low temperature (135.4 K) (see ), with a very low enthalpy value (0.7 ± 0.1 kJ·mol–1), typical of isostructural solid-to-solid transitions, probably due to the disorder in the alkyl chains, as observed by SCXRD (Section ). However, this compound presents two different kinds of anions: butyrates and hydroxyls in its structure, so the thermal behavior is assumed to be more complicated. Three thermal processes are observed at high temperature. A partial decomposition is detected by TGA and DSC at 385 K, followed by a transition at 482.3, indicating that anhydrous manganese(II) butyrate was formed as a product of the previous decomposition. This peak should correspond to the fusion of the anhydrous salt. The mass loss of this first process suggest the formation of a paraffin (coinciding with the mass of propane), as in decomposition of some carboxylic acids, remaining manganese(II) butyrate and other compounds. In this sense, a shoulder is observed by DSC at 470 K, which coincides with starting temperature of manganese(II) carbonate decomposition. This would explain the fact that the enthalpy observed for the fusion of manganese(II) butyrate is apparently higher than the same feature for compound 2, being in this case accompanied by the enthalpy of decomposition of manganese(II) carbonate. Finally, both remaining products decompose, forming MnO in both cases (Figure A). This is the proposed decomposition mechanism for compound 1:

FTIR spectra of these salts were recorded in order to demonstrate some of the features seen by SCXRD. Thus, for example, the spectrum of compound 1 shows a narrow band at 3640 cm–1, corresponding to the O–H stretching of the isolated OH group (that is, without any hydrogen bond due to the absence of any suitable acceptor), in agreement with the solved structure. In the case of compound 2, the presence of H-bonds, between the H atoms of the water molecules and the carboxylates, is evident, revealed by the broad band at around 3225 cm–1 (O–H stretching).

elements.content: The thermal dependence of the χM T product for compound 1 [χM being the susceptibility per six manganese(II) ions for 1] is shown in Figure A. The χM T value at room temperature is ca. 24.31 cm3·mol–1·K corresponding to an effective magnetic moment per Mn(II) ion χeff = [(8 χM T)1/2] of 5.69 μB/Mn(II), which is consistent with the value of 5.92 μB/Mn(II) expected for a magnetically isolated high-spin Mn(II) (S = 5/2) ion with g = 2.00. Upon cooling χM T continuously decreases reaching a value of 3.45 cm3·mol–1·K at 2K. The decrease of χM T is indicative of a small antiferromagnetic interaction. No maximum in the susceptibility curve was observed. The magnetization curve measured at 2 K, which is shown in , exhibits a linear behavior, in all the range of applied magnetic field, which is in agreement with the antiferromagnetic response of this compound at low temperature. As previously said, the possibility of long-range antiferromagnetic order was tested involving neutron diffraction techniques, but there was not signal of magnetic phase transition above 1.5 K (see ).

elements.content: On the basis of the crystal structure of 1, there are 15 different routes of magnetic exchange among the different manganese ions (see of the ), with a Mn···Mn separation ranged from 3.265(2) to 6.215(2) Å. The complication of the magnetic model precluded analyzing the magnetic behavior through an analytical expression. The antiferromagnetic coupling found for 1 is due to the competition among the different bridges between manganese(II) ions. Manganese complexes having the same (μ-OH)(μ-carboxylate), (μ-COO)(μ-carboxylate), bis(μ-COO)(μ-carboxylate) and (μ-OH)(μ-COO)(μ-carboxylate) exchange pathways show a different exchange coupling, from F toward AF, as a function of the Mn···Mn separation and the angle between them through the oxo-bridges. The single carboxylate bridges show a weak antiferromagnetic coupling, with the exception of the syn–syn carboxylate bridge, which is well-known to cause a non-negligible antiferromagnetic coupling, as evidenced by the large number of magneto-structural studies on acetato-bridged dicopper(II) complexes.

elements.content: The magnetic behavior of [Mn5(but)10(H2O)2] n is shown in Figure B in the form of χM T versus T plot (χM is the magnetic susceptibility per five Mn(II) ions). This curve shows that at room temperature the χM T value (20.59 cm3 mol–1K) corresponds to an effective magnetic moment per Mn(II) ion χeff [=(8χM T)1/2] of 5.74 μB/Mn(II), consistent with the value expected for a magnetically isolated high-spin Mn(II) (S = 5/2) ion with g = 2.00. When the temperature decreases the χM T values decrease; a minimum (4.99 cm3 mol–1K) is observed at 7.0 K. Below this minimum, χM T rapidly increases and reaches a very high value of 73.70 cm3 mol–1K at 2 K for an external applied field of 250 Oe. The maximum value of χM T under an external magnetic field of 1000 Oe, is 26.75 cm3 mol–1K at 2 K, lower than the observed for an external magnetic field of 250 Oe (see inset Figure b). The difference is due to the competition at low temperatures between ferromagnetic interactions dominating at low fields and the antiferromagnetic ones present at higher fields. This effect is clearly depicted in the M vs H plot where at 1000 Oe the curve is far from the region of linearity, where χM is independent of H and the relation M = χM H stands ( of the ). The sudden increase of χM T value at 7.0 K indicates ferrimagnetic type behavior, due to the noncancellation of homometallic spins. On the basis of the crystal structure, the non-complete compensation of the antiferromagnetic coupling should produce a long-range ferromagnetic order. This option was studied through the dependence of the ac magnetic susceptibility, but no maximum was observed in the out-of-phase (χ″) signal for temperature above 2 K.

elements.content: The magnetization curve, which is shown in of the , exhibits an increase of magnetization above the Brillouin curve, calculated from five noninteracting Mn(II) ions (red line, S = 5/2, g = 2.00). In the range of external applied field from 0 to 175 Oe, this behavior indicates the presence of ferromagnetic interactions, which is in agreement with the ferromagnetic response of this compound at low temperature. Above this external applied field, the occurrence of moderate antiferromagnetic interactions is confirmed by the huge separation between the Brillouin law and the experimental data. The value of magnetization at saturation corresponds to 5.04 μB measured at 5 T, a value corresponding to one magnetically isolated high-spin (see Brillouin curve, dark red line in of the , calculated for one Mn(II) (S = 5/2) ion with g = 2.00).

elements.content: The magnetic behavior of 2 is due to the competition between the 10 different routes of magnetic exchange among the different manganese ions (see of the ). Compound 2 has an extra (μ-COO)bis(μ-carboxylate) bridge with respect to those bridges observed in 1, which has a remarkable antiferromagnetic behavior due to the double syn-syn carboxylate bridge. The Mn···Mn separation ranges from 3.2907(7) toward 5.8301(9) Å, similar to those observed in 1. The magnetic behavior shows a global antiferromagnetic behavior up to 7 K. Below this temperature, an increase in the susceptibility was observed due to the complete noncancellation of homometallic spins. The non-compensation of the magnetic moments in this compound is only possible if there is a crystal phase transition from the cubic Ia-3 space group to lower symmetry space group. This option was studied involving neutron powder diffraction in the temperature range of 300–1.5 K, nevertheless no phase transition was observed (see Figure B).

elements.content: The structural studies of two new polynuclear butyrate Mn(II) complexes containing single, double, and triple carboxylato bridges have been carried out involving synchrotron radiation at BM16-ESRF. Compound 1 shows a two-dimensional structure built up from corrugated layers, with six crystallographically independent manganese ions. Compound 2 shows a microporous three-dimensional structure, involving five crystallographically independent manganese ions. The carbon atoms of alkyl chains of several butyrate ligands, in compound 2, present a moderate degree of disorder across two different sites which are coherent with the movement of the alkyl chain (see Section ).
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The structural studies of two new polynuclear butyrate Mn(II) complexes containing single, double, and triple carboxylato bridges have been carried out involving synchrotron radiation at BM16-ESRF. Compound 1 shows a two-dimensional structure built up from corrugated layers, with six crystallographically independent manganese ions. Compound 2 shows a microporous three-dimensional structure, involving five crystallographically independent manganese ions. The carbon atoms of alkyl chains of several butyrate ligands, in compound 2, present a moderate degree of disorder across two different sites which are coherent with the movement of the alkyl chain (see Section ).

elements.content: The thermal study, in the TGA and DSC form, was carried out for the two compounds. The main features observed in them were initially the water loss following the fusion of the anhydrous alkanoate, and the final decomposition producing MnO, the formation of paraffin as result of the decomposition of some butyrate ligands has been proposed to explain the results observed in compound 1. Complex 1 shows a low-energy, solid–solid transition in the temperature range between 150 and 125 K. A small change in the cell parameters was observed by single crystal X-ray diffraction as well as by powder neutron diffraction. This change is assumed as a result of the reorientation of the alkyl chains together with the temperature contraction of the cell parameters.

elements.content: The magnetic studies of compounds 1 and 2 were studied in a magnetometer device in the temperature range of 2–300 K. Both compounds present a global antiferromagnetic behavior, as result of the competition between different magnetic interactions that these compounds present. It is worth noting that an increase of the susceptibility was observed below 7 K in compound 2. This feature is due to the presence of non-compensated magnetic moments of the different manganese ions. The possibility of a long-range ferrimagnetic behavior was tested involving powder neutron diffraction in the temperature range of 1.5–300 K, nevertheless no signal of magnetic ordering was observed in this temperature range. Further studies in the microkelvin range would be desirable for clarifying this point; this work would allow elucidating the existence of long-range ferrimagnetic ordering, that would involve a crystal phase transition breaking the cubic symmetry present in 2.

cln_elements.content:
The structures of the two manganese(II) butyrate-based salts were solved and refined by SCXRD. The main characteristics of these frameworks are described below:

Compound <bold>1</bold> ([Mn<sub>6</sub>(but)<sub>11</sub>(OH)]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub>)

This compound shows a monoclinic unit cell (P21/n), with a structure growing in corrugated layers (2D), across the (1,0,-1) plane, partially parallel to the planes (1,-1,-1) and (1,1,-1) (see Figure A). The layers show a regular packing (with an ABAB stacking sequence), being 23.527(4) and 25.279(4) Å the distance between adjacent A planes at 100 and 298 K, respectively. Regarding the ionic layers, the manganese ions are connected among them involving μ-COO, μ-OH, and different carboxylate bridges describing two different kinds of rings, formed by 18 and 10 manganese atoms, respectively (Figure B). These rings are parallel to the planes (1,-1,-1) and (1,1,-1), forming the corrugated layer structure. The alkyl chains of the butyrate ligands grow upward and downward the ionic planes (manganese atoms and carboxylates). The weak Van der Walls interaction among the alkyls tails of the different planes keeps the layers together, reaching the final 3D assemble observed in Figure A.

Thermal Analysis (TGA and DSC)

The thermal study, both Thermogravimetric Analysis (TGA) and Differential Scanning Calorimetry (DSC), was carried out for the two compounds.

The thermal behavior of compound 2 seems to be simpler than 1 and helps to explain the latter’s decomposition (Figure ). In this sense, salt 2 presents three features: the water loss, the fusion of the anhydrous alkanoate, and the final decomposition producing MnO (Figure B). According to the type of water in compound 2, coordination water, its loss takes place at temperatures above 373 K. Thus, two endothermic peaks are observed by DSC, at 388.5 and 398.0 K. After this process, a fusion of the dehydrated salt, [Mn(but)2] n , is observed at 482.3 K. The anhydrous salt (manganese(II) butyrate) remains stable in the second and following heatings, up to a temperature of around 500 K, where it starts to decompose. This decomposition finishes at around 650 K, producing a residue of MnO, as assessed by TGA.

Magnetic PropertiesComplex <bold>1</bold>

The thermal dependence of the χM T product for compound 1 [χM being the susceptibility per six manganese(II) ions for 1] is shown in Figure A. The χM T value at room temperature is ca. 24.31 cm3·mol–1·K corresponding to an effective magnetic moment per Mn(II) ion χeff = [(8 χM T)1/2] of 5.69 μB/Mn(II), which is consistent with the value of 5.92 μB/Mn(II) expected for a magnetically isolated high-spin Mn(II) (S = 5/2) ion with g = 2.00. Upon cooling χM T continuously decreases reaching a value of 3.45 cm3·mol–1·K at 2K. The decrease of χM T is indicative of a small antiferromagnetic interaction. No maximum in the susceptibility curve was observed. The magnetization curve measured at 2 K, which is shown in , exhibits a linear behavior, in all the range of applied magnetic field, which is in agreement with the antiferromagnetic response of this compound at low temperature. As previously said, the possibility of long-range antiferromagnetic order was tested involving neutron diffraction techniques, but there was not signal of magnetic phase transition above 1.5 K (see ).

Complex <bold>2</bold>

The magnetic behavior of [Mn5(but)10(H2O)2] n is shown in Figure B in the form of χM T versus T plot (χM is the magnetic susceptibility per five Mn(II) ions). This curve shows that at room temperature the χM T value (20.59 cm3 mol–1K) corresponds to an effective magnetic moment per Mn(II) ion χeff [=(8χM T)1/2] of 5.74 μB/Mn(II), consistent with the value expected for a magnetically isolated high-spin Mn(II) (S = 5/2) ion with g = 2.00. When the temperature decreases the χM T values decrease; a minimum (4.99 cm3 mol–1K) is observed at 7.0 K. Below this minimum, χM T rapidly increases and reaches a very high value of 73.70 cm3 mol–1K at 2 K for an external applied field of 250 Oe. The maximum value of χM T under an external magnetic field of 1000 Oe, is 26.75 cm3 mol–1K at 2 K, lower than the observed for an external magnetic field of 250 Oe (see inset Figure b). The difference is due to the competition at low temperatures between ferromagnetic interactions dominating at low fields and the antiferromagnetic ones present at higher fields. This effect is clearly depicted in the M vs H plot where at 1000 Oe the curve is far from the region of linearity, where χM is independent of H and the relation M = χM H stands ( of the ). The sudden increase of χM T value at 7.0 K indicates ferrimagnetic type behavior, due to the noncancellation of homometallic spins. On the basis of the crystal structure, the non-complete compensation of the antiferromagnetic coupling should produce a long-range ferromagnetic order. This option was studied through the dependence of the ac magnetic susceptibility, but no maximum was observed in the out-of-phase (χ″) signal for temperature above 2 K.

<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch1" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<caption>
<title>Different Coordination Modes of Butyrate Ligands, (a) and (b) Modes Are Present in <bold>1</bold>, while (a)–(c) are Present in <bold>2</bold>
</title>
</caption>
<graphic id="gr1" orientation="portrait" position="anchor" xlink:href="cg-2011-00649n_0009.tif"></graphic>
</fig>
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Different Coordination Modes of Butyrate Ligands, (a) and (b) Modes Are Present in 1, while (a)-(c) are Present in 2

cln_elements.content: (A) Unit cell of Mn6(but)11(OH) (1) along the [101] vector, showing the ABAB stacking mode, the weak interaction between planes are mainly due to van der Waals interactions. (B) View along the [10–1] vector, showing the 10 and 18-membered rings (indicated with a blue and a red circle, respectively) formed by the μ-COO, μ-OH, and different carboxylate bridges. (C) Asymmetric unit of Mn6(but)11(OH) at 100 K (Mn 6 (but) 11 (OH) a); the hydroxo group have been represented in blue and the tails of butyrate ligands have been represented in transparence mode for the sake of the picture. (D) Fragment view along the a- and c-axis of compound 1, where the crystal structure acquired at 298 and at 100 K have been represented in green and orange color, respectively.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  (A) Unit cell of Mn6(but)11(OH) (1) along the [101] vector, showing the ABAB stacking mode, the weak interaction between planes are mainly due to van der Waals interactions. (B) View along the [10-1] vector, showing the 10 and 18-membered rings (indicated with a blue and a red circle, respectively) formed by the μ-COO, μ-OH, and different carboxylate bridges. (C) Asymmetric unit of Mn6(but)11(OH) at 100 K (Mn  6  (but)  11  (OH) a); the hydroxo group have been represented in blue and the tails of butyrate ligands have been represented in transparence mode for the sake of the picture. (D) Fragment view along the a- and c-axis of compound 1, where the crystal structure acquired at 298 and at 100 K have been represented in green and orange color, respectively.

cln_elements.content: (A) Unit cell of Mn5(but)10(H2O)2 along the a axis, showing the coordination polyhedra of the Mn(II) atoms in orange, showing the formation of hydrophobic and hydrophilic channels. (B) Fragment view of Mn5(but)10(H2O)2 (2) at 100 K (Mn 5 (but) 10 (H 2 O) 2 a), where the manganese ions of the asymmetric unit have been labeled. C) View of a fragment of the inorganic network, showing the two hydrophilic equivalent rings formed. The water molecules have been represented in blue to help to visualize the hydrophobic and hydrophilic channels; each hydrophobic channel is surrounded by four hydrophilic and vice versa, as shown in Figure A. The tails of butyrate ligands in 2A–2B have been represented in transparent mode, while in 2C they have been completely omitted for the clarity of the picture.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  (A) Unit cell of Mn5(but)10(H2O)2 along the a axis, showing the coordination polyhedra of the Mn(II) atoms in orange, showing the formation of hydrophobic and hydrophilic channels. (B) Fragment view of Mn5(but)10(H2O)2 (2) at 100 K (Mn  5  (but)  10  (H  2  O)  2  a), where the manganese ions of the asymmetric unit have been labeled. C) View of a fragment of the inorganic network, showing the two hydrophilic equivalent rings formed. The water molecules have been represented in blue to help to visualize the hydrophobic and hydrophilic channels; each hydrophobic channel is surrounded by four hydrophilic and vice versa, as shown in Figure A. The tails of butyrate ligands in 2A-2B have been represented in transparent mode, while in 2C they have been completely omitted for the clarity of the picture.
